snippet: The permissibility of beta blockers in golf’s top level has come into focus anew this week after Charlie Beljan won a PGA Tour event Sunday, two days after being hospitalized with a panic attack.
abstract: Permissibility of beta blockers in professional golf has come under new scrutiny after Charlie Beljan won PGA Tour event two days after being hospitalized with panic attack; drug is officially banned by the PGA and LPGA, but has become problematic because it can be used to treat both high blood pressure and jittery nerves that can impede a golfer's game.
lead_paragraph: The permissibility of beta blockers in golf’s top level has come into focus anew this week after Charlie Beljan won a PGA Tour event Sunday, two days after being hospitalized with a panic attack.

headline.seo: Beta Blockers May Calm Nerves, Keeping Them Banned by PGA and L.P.G.A.
headline.main: Heart Medications May Also Calm Nerves, Keeping Them Banned
headline.print_headline: Drugs to Treat Heart May Also Calm Nerves, Keeping Them Banned
